title: Friday, 26th January, 2018
bodyHTML:
Blank canvas good morning all
Tom Dalgleish Happy Australia Day everyone
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Good morning, welcome, hello, hi, hola.

BE11:04am

Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's etc etc etc.

Tom Dalgleish since you had a bit to do with it
Soundbuy Morning all..........
Grouchmonkey Morning. Burns night. What a bad idea that was.
Barkap GSK coming back, seems to have inflected
FATDAZ Morning all Thanks Tom ( I work for the Aussies now )
BE11:05am

And just looking at the analytics page this morning, we seem to have some competition for eyeballs from the letters page .....

11:04 am
BE11:05am

https://www.ft.com/comment/letters

Manxish Morning each
BE11:05am

Frankly, the FT ought to be ashamed of itself

BE11:05am

Far worse horrors need your attention

11:05 am
BE11:05am

In 30 years there has been not one formal complaint about this charity event

BE11:05am

Turn your firepower on the Carillion story

BE11:06am

Yep, fair enough on Carillion, we've barely mentioned that one.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

Just the twelve stories this week so far: https://www.ft.com...ions/Carillion_PLC

DerivedCategory Morning all
BE11:07am

Anyway, rather than divert you elsewhere, we should push on with the day job.

undefined
11:08 am
BE11:08am

FTSE up! Everything up! Ahead 0.5% at pixel, 7656.

BE11:09am

Largely FX driven on the back of UK GDP and ahead of US data/Trump saying whatever.

BE11:10am

Anyway, was just reading an interesting strategy thing from Robert Kerr at Redburn.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Who runs their IDEAS team.

BE11:10am

The gist of it is that earnings forecasts are stabilising after six years of cuts.

BE11:11am

Expectations now ticking higher for most cyclicals. Oils, mining, autos, airlines .... even (maybe, a bit) the financial sector.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

What makes that important is that European stocks are, according to them, as cheap as they were in 2008.

FATDAZ Re Carillion do we know how much HMT has forked out for work that wont be completed by CLLN and may have to be payed for again ?
BE11:11am

At least in terms of ROCE over WACC.

ValencianBull morning
BE11:11am

Plus, the trailing PE is only just at 26-year through-the-cycle average.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

So .........

BE11:12am

As the cost of capital rises, the market should go back to pricing what it can see. That means that the link between earnings revisions, estimates momentum and direction and performance should be restored.

Deep Breath everyone... @BE Robert Kerr should always be referred to as The Reverend
red as zirp is wound back, funding junk no longer becomes worthwhile
BE11:13am

So, buy the upgrades and pray that the central bank normalisation doesn't accidentally tank things.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

In the long term, the direction of market change has coincided with, or prededed, the direction of change for market consensus forecasts ("new information"), as analyst revisions activity confirms or counters anticipation by the market. This has been disrupted while ultra-loose monetary policy dominated other considerations (shaded area). In Europe, all equity market advance in 2012-15 was due to re-rating (from low levels) rather than earnings growth or revisions.

JimboRock Anything on Imperial Brands recent slide please
BE11:13am

BE11:14am

Which is kind of counter intuitive to a lot of the "dying days of the bull run" stuff we've been hearing lately.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Anyway, I thought it was interesting.

undefined
BE11:14am

@JimboRock mentions Imperial ......

11:15 am
BE11:15am

.... though I'm not sure what we can say that hasn't already been said.

BE11:15am

Sterling, clearly, is turning into a headwind.

Pseudonym @Grouchmonkey We bump Burns to the weekend, surely you didn't do it on a school night?
red IMB reverting t0 10 and 15yr trendlines after period of outperformance. c. 2800 and 2550p.
BE11:16am

Plus there was Japan Tobacco's new CEO Masamichi Terabatake saying he's not interested in complicated M&A.

Grouchmonkey @pseudonym seemed a good idea at the time
Otter Hello online friendos
FATDAZ @BE when you have an open ended buyer(s) with trillions to spend prices rise that's simple supply and demand ........no need for intuition
11:16 am
BE11:17am

That was January 16th? Imperial's been a straight line downwards since then, which hints at the amount of event-driven money that has to exit.

Mark Shapland London Stock Exchange merger .........again?
red IMB be patience. it will be a buy. but not yet. or at least better times to buy.
Pseudonym @BE I was pondering the FT's P-Club stories. What has it actually achieved in practice? One less charity? Some embarrassed but quite possibly innocent people? Half a million quid less in the coffers of GOSH? Perhaps some girls won't get groped in future, although more likely the events will be more cautiously arranged.
IslandDweller Pseudonym. It's called out rank hypocrits. The sort of CEO who signs a diversity policy then goes to an event like this. Ocado looking at you
BE11:19am

Because, if not Japan Tobacco, who? You're looking at a very very complicated carve-up between the majors or something leftfield like China National Tobacco Corp.

Pharma @FATDAZ, in all the talk about how much the government is spending re. Carillion, it hasn't been clear to me why they would have paid in advance. If they did, then that is scandalous, but it seems much more likely they paid in arrears, or on completion, in which case losses are much smaller.
red as for Japan Tobacco. when the price is right.
BE11:19am

And given Imperial's 10% or so market share in the US, is China National even an option any more? However, we've been over this about a thousand times already.

Noddy Boffin I have a question for ROTR: where do you go to for research/discussion on US equities?
December69 CNTP Can't do it, its limited further exposure according to its mgmt (maybe things have changed)?
red i am interested 25-28 quid. i expect it may see close to 20 quid before JT sees the $ signs and cant hold off any longer. all about the bottom line.
Pharma @Pseudonym, the £0.5m is entirely the fault of the GOSH trustees, not the FT.
11:20 am
BE11:20am

Anyway, the only new thing on Imps and the tobacco stocks this week is the TPSAC meeting on iQOS.

red @Noddy Boffinits btfd didnt u know? but seriously best to look at things yourself. and what you dont understand or cant set a case for, stay away from.
Pseudonym @IslandDweller Oh I agree, but they'll do it anyway. There'll be some waitresses being groped at Davos as we write.
BE11:21am

Huge for the vaping / heat not burn lobbyists. Handy chart via JPM.

FATDAZ @Pharma I hope so but we shall see imagine OBR or similar will look into it
BE11:22am

Otter A fun alternative is snus which is norwegian tobacco in a teabag which hides inside your lip
11:22 am
BE11:22am

And a bit of comment.

IslandDweller @Pseudonym. That's a defeatist approach. I'm glad to see it tackled
TheManwithaLongChin not sure why that means the FT shouldn't report groping in London
BE11:23am

1) The vote results from a science perspective were, by our count, significantly better than the headline votes (i.e. issues with question language overshadowed the strength of PM’s data, in our view); 2) it is now less probable that the FDA grants exposure MRTP to PM, although we still see small chances of obtaining a “decaffeinated approval” while the chances of MRTP on a second application have increased substantially; 3) we believe PM is likely to obtain PMTA; and 4) we neither see a change to the NNP equity story nor a risk to current favorable heat-not-burn taxation and believe regulators outside the US will continue embracing the category. Accordingly, we believe PM’s share price reaction was slightly excessive and would buy on weakness if the TPSAC’s decision continues to weigh on the stock. We believe the read-across to BAT and Imperial is positive (BTI US -1% overnight unjustified, in our view) while the read to SWMA is neutral.

joebloggs anything on Temenos?
undefined
pancakes or waffles @Otter I learnt of that in Moneyball!
11:23 am
BE11:23am

ROTR, can I make a suggestion?

red not aimed at that particular event but these days seems plenty of folks desperately looking for something to be offended by. another social media gift.
Pharma @FATDAZ, hope so, but the general population will still have the view that signing a £xBn contract will have lead directly to £xBn being lost. Media not helping on this really.
JimboRock Many thanks for the IMB update
BE11:24am

I know we're an open, freewheeling forum here, but perhaps a better place to discuss the morality and merits of reporting repulsive behaviour would be at your golf clubs.

Tom Dalgleish Much media uproar is an excuse for ageism
IslandDweller BE - noted but I wouldn't be seen dead in a golf club
Otter @pancakes I have not seen this famous baseball film
BE11:25am

We, after all, have stocks to talk about.

11:25 am
undefined
red BE - i take offence to your suggestion. i dont go to a golf club and feel left out. can i complain on facebook or something.
FATDAZ @Pharma MMS is largely a disgrace these days Facts or context rarely reported just a recycled left wing narrative
BE11:26am

Temenos? Sure, I guess so.

pancakes or waffles @Otter or book! Both are excellent if you find the time. I found the book much better though in terms of interesting information and context
FATDAZ @Phamrma i meant MSM
BE11:27am

Back down a bit today. Lower by 3% or so, having gone parabolic yesterday.

Otter @Pancakes thank you for the tip.
FATDAZ @BE Pharma and I a discussing MSM reporting of Carillion :) That was stock once upon a time
11:27 am
BE11:28am

The first reason for yesterday's move was comments from Nordea saying their rollout of Temenos .... stuff ........ was going to plan and budget.

BE11:28am

Given Nordea's a flagship contract for Temenos, this is very good news. Though it's probably not 18% on the price good.

Mouselet Good morning assorted capitalists
December69 @FDaz CLLN, the ever growing list of non-dividend stocks that paid a dividend. Not the best way to run a low margin business reliant on changes to quoted works.
BE11:29am

The other angle ..... ah, here's Kepler.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Microsoft and Softbank are names that often come up. However, given current valuation and the premium needed, a buyer would need to pay over 50x earnings, which may be hard to justify. The acquisition of ARM by Softbank at high multiples and a huge premium (but also after a falling sterling) and the recent USD5bn loan raised by Softbank have given support to this hypothesis.

FATDAZ Temenos Written up by Kepler I see
#REF! Been told at work that should take up golf for networking. But it seems expensive and needlessly dull. I'm a millenial, can't I just snapchat ppl?
BE11:29am

We revise up our growth estimates from 2018E onwards to account for the dollar weakness and better growth prospects mid-term. We now expect c. 15% growth reported in 2018, including 4pp from forex tailwinds and 1.5pp from Rubik (+9.7% LFL). We also increase licence sales for 2019-20 by 150bps to +12% YOY and now expect close to 11% total revenue growth in both years.

BE11:30am

We add CHF11 to our target price, more than half coming from the Nordea comments and the decision to slightly lift medium-term growth, the rest from rolling over our DCF with one quarter less. Speculation is also likely to sustain the shares, as we cannot completely rule out a takeover on the company despite its valuation. The shares are expensive and are a buy and hold story, and some better entry points are possible ahead. The delivery of an in-line/slight beat on 2017 earnings on 13 February may, as last year, provide an opportunity to buy. Management will keep reinvesting in sales and marketing rather than letting margins go through the roof, and hence we do not expect major beats on EPS. High multiples justified, Buy maintained.

FATDAZ @december69 no its not the whole affair n is a very poor reflection on UK corporate governance
tja But Snap has gone below $14 again
December69 Agreed, there'ws more out there as well
BBOC Popularity of golf is absolutely crumbling apparently. Average age of club member soaring
Soundbuy Prefer the 19th hole without all that mowing...........that'd be the pub I guess....
FATDAZ @December 69 no doubt but where are the regulators in all this ?
Mouselet The people who would otherwise be golfers have turned into the middle-aged men in lycra
#REF! @Soundbuy can I play Everyboady's Golf in a pub, does that count?
Pharma Now all we need to do is define defunct golf clubs as brownfield sites, and the housing shortage is fixed.
11:31 am
BE11:31am

Can I suggest in passing that, when the EV's up at nearly 21 times ebitda, the possibility of a takeover needs to be weighed carefully against the possibility that the company will use its inflated value as an acquisition currency .....

December69 BBOC, interesting that it's been in decline for 18 months, ironically some suggest it's almost to the day Tiger Woods's perception changed.
Mouselet Do you need regulators when you have investors who say 'err, dividend cover -173%, let's not buy that one?'
BE11:32am

.... good luck to all holders, though.

undefined
Soundbuy @BBOC Somerset's lost a fair few clubs over the last 5 yrs or so.......
11:32 am
BE11:32am

Mentioning golf was a terrible mistake. I understand that now.

Bonnemort Middle classes being hollowed out, golf boom of 80s / 90s being reversed. Used to be one club near me, now 3.
Mouselet There is a bit of me that is quite uneasy about public companies borrowing money at all: once they're on the stock market they should be obtaining money mostly by rights issue, so that the people whose money is at risk when they lose it are the important ones
Soundbuy More cyclists than ever on the roads........
Pharma @Mouselet, do you think those two pastimes speak to an underlying need/desire to dress up in really stupid clothes?
Miss Piggy @BE; haha
BE11:33am

Anyhoo .... let's get on.

GVC Holdings PLC (GVC:LSE): Last: 929.50, down 18.5 (-1.95%), High: 931.00, Low: 902.00, Volume: 4.80m
Noddy Boffin Golf v bad for environment, because they spray the grass with weedkiller.
#REF! @BE sorry...
Manxish any grey on GVC?
FATDAZ @Mouselett to my mind bidding on contracts you know you will make losses on and plundering cash flow and defereing creditors is reckless and tantamount to fraud so I would say yes
December69 @BE I'm surprised you made it today with 'Burns'
Bonnemort @Soundbuy - types who used to buy carbon fibre clubs now buy carbon fibre bikes
11:34 am
BE11:34am

Announcement post close yesterday about Greek tax authorities putting on the squeeze.

Grouchmonkey Since there's not much to say on stocks, is there any macro on currencies to celebrate the GBK passing the pre-referendum high water mark?
Mouselet I can see that Samsung probably doesn't want to do a rights issue each time it wants to build a new fab, but I'm not sure why that's not just because rights issues are associated with failing companies
Pharma @FATDAZ, what you describe is trading while insolvent, so if proven the directors are in trouble.
BE11:35am

Which dates back to its Sportingbet acquisition.

BE11:35am

The best coverage of the story's in a thing called GamblingCompliance: https://gamblingco...-licence-bid-fears

Mouselet Is there much stopping the Government from saying 'Government contracts will be paid in full in advance, but will be let only to companies who pay subcontractors in full in advance'?
Miss Piggy What is a New Information Index re that graph?
FATDAZ @bonnemort yes there are at least 4 shops around spitalfields that sell bikes and or their paraphernalia
red sportingbet. back in the day. an ofex charm. the original dotcom bubble.
#REF! @Mouselet, as a shareholder in a public company, debt is a cheaper source of capital. Why would I want more dilutive equity issuance with ROE>debt cost?
11:36 am
BE11:36am

I'll quote a par or two rather than breaching their paywall.

BE11:36am

GVC wants to continue to operate in the country but the size of the fine, which equates to around a quarter of the firm’s annual revenue, and any protracted legal case would at the very least cast doubt on its chances of picking up a licence, if the new system is adopted.

Pharma @Mouselet on debt, it's the tax, isn't it? Interest deductible, payments to shareholders not.
FATDAZ @Pharm exactly but that wont help the employees pensioners sub contractors etc
#REF! Depends on the nature of business I suppose. If you have a 20 year contact with a high grade customer, why fund with equity? Inefficient
Otter It would make me happy to hear my internet friend's weekend plans. I plan to buy a brace of widgeon from the game dealer and roast them for sunday tea.
BE11:38am

So, this is all to do with transitional licences, which came in in 2011 with the expectation of licences being made permanent later.

doeswalk @#REF! coz the creditors will be senior to me and wield power in times of distress
11:38 am
BE11:38am

That never happened.

Manxish For what it's worth, varoufakis' most recent book frequently mentioned how anti-Gambling/Gaming the Syriza Govt was/is.
Helen78 So GVC is out of Turkey, soon to be out of Greece, then all they have to worry about is German slots
BE11:39am

And Greece is a regulatory nightmare because OPAP, the state operator, claims an online betting monopoly until 2020

BE11:39am

Sources in Greece told GamblingCompliance that the GVC tax assessment was “enormous because the tax authority refused, due to insufficient documentation, to deduct winnings payments to the players from the turnover of the operator”

Pseudonym @BE Noted re-morality, but it was you that kicked off on it.
11:39 am
BE11:39am

Let me grab some sellside.

BE11:40am

Here's Barclays.

BE11:40am

The total tax ‘bill’ is €186.77m. This is substantially higher by multiples of the total revenue generated by the subsidiary during the period. This appears contentious to us. GVC has launched an appeal. GVC thinks it has strong grounds for appeal, believing the tax bill is ‘widely exaggerated.’ So that GVC’s subsidiary (which is licensed, pays taxes and is established in the market) can continue to trade, GVC plans to pay €7.8m/month over the next 24 months.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

This news will concern investors. The €200m provision is c. 6% of GVC’s market cap. We think the share price will decline by at least this much tomorrow first thing. We would see this as a buying opportunity. The share price may fall more due to legacy tax concerns. We note that 888’s share price reacted in a similar way after announcing a German tax provision in September last year. We note: 1) this is not a GVC specific issue. 2) The provision will not impact FY17 underlying EBITDA nor guidance going forward in our view (albeit Net Debt will be higher). 3) GVC continues to operate in Greece, which is a top 10 market for the company. 4) Investors will understandably worry that GVC could be hit with a similar retrospective tax bill (e.g. for Turkey, but we note that GVC no longer owns that business). 5) We think the appeal process may be a protracted affair so we doubt the issue will be resolved soon. 6) GVC’s revenues have never have been 100% regulated, which will always suppress its multiple, in our view.

Sails 'Otter, so widgeon are duck ? Sound delicious. My plan is to consume a beef and dill stew while watching an old film on Sunday afternoon, possibly after a morning cycle ride (in lycra of course)
BE11:41am

So ..... GVC's €200m provision works out at 58p per current GVC share, or 31p post Ladbrokes merger

FATDAZ Manxish but isn't OPAP a state run gambling concern ?
December69 Wonder which major company is impacted by Turkey and prepaid cards out of Greece? Major gambling company that is...answers on a post card to...
#REF! @doeswalk yeah of course a tail risk that you should hopefully get compensated with by higher returns than the debt owners.
Pharma @FATDAZ, so make sure they are flogged around the fleet, pour encourager les autres.
BE11:42am

Peek Hunt is rather withering ......

11:42 am
BE11:42am

The demand by the tax authorities in Greece for €187m makes
no sense to us, except that it highlights that GVC is in a better
balance sheet position than Greece. Assuming that an €8m per
month/24-month payment plan is agreed (prior to appeal), the
interim arrangements will be comfortably borne by the business.

FATDAZ @Pharma agreed :)
BE11:42am

Berenberg also unfussed, relatively.

BE11:43am

We believe that the amount of tax demanded by Greece grossly overstates how much GVC should owe in back taxes. We estimate that the tax-only component of the request from Greek tax authorities should be around EUR10m. Also, we note that the current Greek business is licensed and that the company has been regularly paying gaming taxes on it since 2013. As such, is no threat to the company’s legitimacy in Greece. We do not believe there is any threat to the completion of the LCL acquisition.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

That said, even if the ruling ultimately finds in favour of GVC, it could take a long time for the company to recover the money from Greece, and it may not recoup the full amount. We have therefore factored into our GVC price target a 50% likelihood that it will end up not recovering the full EUR200m, which has shaved 30p off our previous price target of £11 (now £10.70). While initial market reaction is likely to be negative today, we would remind investors that, even in the worst-case scenario, EUR200m represents c6% of GVC’s standalone market cap, and 3% of the combined GVC-LCL group.

Bonnemort @BE - probably makes a lot of sense to the Greek tax people, though
BE11:44am

Davy, similar.

BE11:45am

News that Greek tax authorities have made a claim of €187m against GVC relating to its Sportingbet subsidiary’s operations in the country in 2010 and 2011 looks ridiculous on the face of it. The claim is a multiple of revenue generated by the business in Greece during that time and, therefore, we would be confident that the ultimate settlement of this claim will be for materially less than (a fraction of) the amount provisioned (€200m). The group has agreed to start paying monthly instalments of €7.8m while it appeals, a pre-condition to remaining operational there. But even doing so, the group’s financial leverage target of 3x should not be breached.
Therefore, as long as the Ladbrokes Coral (LCL) Board are
satisfied that this does not materially change things, it should be
no more than an unwelcome distraction that will be resolved in the years ahead.

December69 so costs are now based on market cap rather than % turnover/profits. On that basis, the world has lost the plot!
doeswalk If you believe in efficient markets the debt equity should be priced perfectly according to risk/reward although I suppose in recent times you have central bank actions to add to the equation
11:45 am
BE11:46am

Canaccord, similar.

Tom Dalgleish Reminds me of some Indian Tax office claims that meander on for 10 years then fizzle out
BE11:46am

It has been a difficult week for the Online Gaming sector, following on from press reports pointing to a rising risk of a painful impact from the Triennial Review for GVC's soon-to-be-acquired Ladbrokes Coral (LCL-LSE : 172p | Buy). GVC's offer structure provided plenty of protection from the Triennial review, and arguably, it would be perfectly happy to take on a shrunk-down (and cheaper) LCL retail estate. The Greek fine looks more materially negative. We still see plenty of upside from the Ladbrokes combination, and even assuming the full €187m cash impact, a combined GVC/LCL would see Debt/Ebitda rise from c.2.8x to c.3.0x, so not a material stretch. But given that Greece represents real cash out, and the timing of any appeal is uncertain, we adjust our TP for the Net present value of the €187m cash hit, coming down from 1120p to 1070p. We retain our Buy recommendation.

Ladbrokes Coral Group PLC (LCL:LSE): Last: 170.50, down 1.7 (-0.99%), High: 170.90, Low: 165.70, Volume: 5.98m
Grouchmonkey @Tom Dalgleish Cairn?
December69 Cairn like @Tom
Tom Dalgleish ANZ actually
Manxish @FATDAZ yes, but I understand they are less accommodating of private operators - tending to see gaming as having a regressive social impact. In any event, may have contributed to their stance re: GVC
Tom Dalgleish So agree to pay each month but never do LOL
11:47 am
BE11:48am

Something about this reminds me of that claim against Acacia launched by the Tanzanian government for $190bn.

Pharma The Greeks only need to drag the appeal out for 2 years and they have the full €200m. If they then end up owing GVC money, they can then offer them the same repayment terms that their other creditors enjoy.
Ca$hMoney John Laing infra fund down heavy on the year - but sposedly Carillion won't impact?
BE11:49am

Which was an hilarious number, with un-hilarious consequences.

undefined
FATDAZ @Manxish ironic that a nation made avoiding tax an artform should know have staunch view on regressive businesses
Flaneur Are there any more major carillion-style zombie companies that need endless QE out there?
Manxish @FATDAZ quite
11:49 am
BE11:50am

(@Kiwi-juice: we have to be wary of libel here, which can include mistaken identity. Apologies for the delete.)

BE11:50am

Okay, what else to mention?

BE11:50am

Reference to GSK earlier.

Pharma @Flaneur, depends whether you think loss-making tech companies (Uber, Tesla) are a product of QE
11:51 am
GlaxoSmithKline PLC (GSK:LSE): Last: 1,350, up 15.2 (+1.14%), High: 1,354, Low: 1,335, Volume: 2.43m
doeswalk @Flaneur for sure, it's just knowing who they are
FATDAZ @Flanneur I would look at other outsourcers for a start how would there balance sheets fare under a forensic microscope I wonder
red @Flaneur interserve and provident financial, the later largely execution risk
BE11:51am

Positive news on Revlar Ellipda labelling on the tape, which is useful rather than significant.

Kiwi-juice BE apologies - you are rightI am super sensitive about the whole issue. I'll stop
BE11:52am

We also have a push from Redburn.

Kiwi-juice @flaneur GE?
11:53 am
BE11:54am

Starts by noting that the divi is now 6%, suggesting some doubt on whether Emma Walmsley will keep it.

FATDAZ I see RBC has a note out on Internet M&A
BE11:54am

(A theme we've touched on repeatedly here and elsewhere.)

madrugada OPAP shops are as ubiquitous in Greece as bookies in the U.K. Most offer football betting and U.K. greyhound racing. Another outlet has some UK, French, South African and Greek horse racing , though it has a limited number of races.
BE11:55am

Such argument misses the point. The balance sheet can be flexed harder than is appreciated and our work argues a dividend cut is unlikely. Moreover, regardless of what is purchased or how it is funded, business development in consumer offers an epochal opportunity. It diversifies GSK beyond HIV, shores up cash flows to support pharma investment and positions the group for a potential split over the longer term. To focus solely on the dividend is to be in danger of overlooking the broader narrative.

FATDAZ Asos, Zalando and Just eat feature as poss acqn targets
Pharma @Kiwi-juice, interesting. The current problems remind me of comments from Immelt when they were at their peak, basically stating that they gamed earnings by shifting forward revenue if one or other division was weak that quarter.
11:55 am
BE11:55am

Redburn also challenges the idea that Walmsley will be a business-as-usual CEO.

Swedish Chef Thx for Glax. Your colleagues @ investors chronicle reckon div cut v possible
BE11:57am

She's already taken a flamethrower to several layers of management and rejigged the R&D budget, with a lot of stuff said about cash generation and capital discipline.

BE11:57am

Cultural change at a company the size of GSK will take time to be reflected n the multiple, but, at the current valuation and with an appetising array of opportunities, the risk-reward is in its favour. In our best case scenario, the shares could trade towards 2000p by 2020. We upgrade our recommendation to Buy.

doeswalk interesting to know if some of the scandals that have effected Japanese companies that have come to light recently are down to Japanese culture or human nature
madrugada Swedish Chef: IC just don’t like GSK.
Pharma #GE correction, I think it was Welch, not Immelt, who praised their reporting flexibility.
11:59 am
BE11:59am

Just spinning through the detail .....

BE12:00pm

If the company were to finance the Novartis put at £9.5bn and the Pfizer business at $16bn, we argue this could be done without a dividend cut – gearing would be uncomfortable in the very short term, but manageable.

Kiwi-juice GE went nowhere in 15 years now. The "capital allocation magic' was just buying high beta levered stuff. It will take years unwind
Kiwi-juice GSK needs to bite the bullet and cut the divi. No strategic room when divi spending = FCFEspecially for Pharma, remember that assets have a finite life
red sre GE shares may be down but still 150bn mkt cap. still a lot of money even at the current share price. i think it will take a bid from berkshire eventually to turn it around. but i cant see any bid before 10 bucks as u have to give some sort of premium
BE12:01pm

.... which looks brave, but whatever.

12:01 pm
undefined
BE12:02pm

Cripes!

FATDAZ @kiwi juice you should seek out the agony and the ecstasy by JPM Asset management a great critique of the equity lifecycle
Kiwi-juice Berkshire does not buy restructuring stories since they bought Berkshire 50 years ago.

https://www.ft.com/cryptocurrencies

12:02 pm
